general: This law changes how telecom companies can use leased properties like buildings or land to install communication equipment like cell phone towers or fiber optic cables. Before, these companies had to follow strict rules when using these properties. Now, they have more freedom to do so as long as they follow some basic guidelines. This should make it easier for them to provide better internet and phone service to people all over the UK.

series.short: "UK Government Introduces New Legislation to Improve Electronic Communications Network Installation in Leased Properties"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has introduced a new legislation, Telecommunications Infrastructure (Leasehold Property) Act 2021, to improve the process of installing electronic communications networks in leased properties.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation aims to make it easier for telecom operators to obtain the necessary rights to install and maintain electronic communications networks in leased premises by imposing an agreement on the required grantor.
* Simplified point 3: The agreement imposes on the operator and the required grantor an agreement by which the required grantor confers on the operator a code right to install and maintain electronic communications networks in the leased premises.
* Simplified point 4: The code right allows the operator to exercise the agreement in respect of the connected land, which is defined as the land in common ownership with the target premises.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation provides for the court to make an order imposing an agreement on the required grantor if the operator has given the required grantor two warning notices and a final notice, and the required grantor has not responded to the operator.
* Simplified point 6: The agreement may include terms relating to the provision of details of the works to be carried out, obtaining consent and indemnification, maintenance and upgrading of apparatus, and assignment of the agreement.
* Simplified point 7: The Part 4A code right may be exercised by the operator in respect of the connected land for the provision of an electronic communications service to the target premises and other premises, subject to certain conditions.
* Simplified point 8: The Part 4A code right ceases to be conferred on the operator if a replacement agreement comes into effect, or if the right has not ceased to have that effect as mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b) before the end of the specified period.
* Simplified point 9: The required grantor has the right to require the operator to remove any electronic communications apparatus placed on the connected land in the exercise of a Part 4A code right which has ceased to have effect.
* Simplified point 10: The legislation provides for compensation to be paid to the required grantor for any loss or damage sustained or to be sustained as a result of the exercise of the Part 4A code right.

series.short: "Telecommunications Infrastructure Regulation Act 2021: Commencement and Transitional Provisions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section outlines the extent and commencement of the Act, stating that it applies to England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, with certain provisions coming into force on the day the Act is passed and others being appointed by the Secretary of State through regulations.
* Simplified point 2: The Act can be cited as the Telecommunications Infrastructure (Leasehold Property) Act 2021, and regulations made under it are to be made by statutory instrument.
* Simplified point 3: The Act makes transitional provisions for the coming into force of its provisions, allowing the Secretary of State to appoint different days for different purposes.
* Simplified point 4: The Act gives the Secretary of State the power to make regulations under Part 4A of Schedule 3A to the Communications Act 2003, as inserted by section 1 of this Act.

series.short: "UK Landlords Must Allow Telecom Network Installations Under New Law"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has introduced a new law, Telecommunications Infrastructure (Leasehold Property) Act 2021, to improve installation of electronic communication networks in rented properties.
* Simplified point 2: The law requires landlords to agree to allow telecom companies to install and maintain network infrastructure in their properties.
* Simplified point 3: If the landlord fails to respond, the telecom company can apply to the courts for an order to install the infrastructure.
* Simplified point 4: The law also includes provisions for compensation to be paid to landlords for any losses or damages caused by the installation of the infrastructure.

summary: The UK government has created a new law called the Telecommunications Infrastructure (Leasehold Property) Act 2021 to help telecom companies install and maintain electronic communication networks in rental properties more easily. Under this law, telecom companies can get permission from property owners to place equipment like cell towers or fiber optic cables on their land without having to go to court first. If the owner doesn't respond within a certain time frame, the company can start work anyway. The law also says that the company must pay fair compensation to the owner if they cause any damage or loss. Additionally, the law sets up rules for how these agreements between telecom companies and property owners should be written and enforced.
